title: Zbigniew Bieńkowski
text:
Zbigniew Bieńkowski (31 August 1913, in <a href="Warsaw">Warsaw</a> — 23 February 1994) was a Polish <a href="poet">poet</a>, <a href="Literary%20criticism">literary critic</a>, <a href="translation">translator</a> and <a href="essay">essay</a>ist.
Biography.
Bieńkowski graduated in 1931 from the <a href="Gymnasium%20%28school%29">Gymnasium</a> XX Marian in <a href="Bielany">Bielany</a> near <a href="Warsaw">Warsaw</a>. From 1932 to 1939 he studied at the <a href="University%20of%20Warsaw">University of Warsaw</a> both <a href="Legal%20education">law</a> at the Faculty of Law, as well as at the Faculty of Humanities. Bieńkowski received a one-year scholarship from the <a href="Sorbonne">Sorbonne</a> and moved to <a href="Paris">Paris</a> in 1938. In 1939 he moved to <a href="Italy">Italy</a> and then to <a href="Yugoslavia">Yugoslavia</a>, where he was caught by the outbreak of <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. He returned to Poland during the Nazi occupation. He fought as a soldier for the <a href="Armia%20Krajowa">Armia Krajowa</a>, and participated in the <a href="Warsaw%20Uprising">Warsaw Uprising</a>.
After the war he worked in the editorial department of the "<a href="Rzeczpospolita%20%28newspaper%29">Rzeczpospolita</a>" daily, then in the weekly "Odrodzenie" and monthly "<a href="Tw%C3%B3rczo%C5%9B%C4%87">Twórczość</a>".
In 1960 he married <a href="Ma%C5%82gorzata%20Hillar">Małgorzata Hillar</a>.
Bieńkowski was a member of the Polish <a href="International%20PEN">PEN Organization</a> from 1966 to 1972.
The authors on which he focused as a translator include: <a href="Charles%20Baudelaire">Charles Baudelaire</a>, <a href="Victor%20Hugo">Victor Hugo</a>, <a href="Mikhail%20Lermontov">Mikhail Lermontov</a>, <a href="Saint-John%20Perse">Saint-John Perse</a>, <a href="Paul%20%C3%89luard">Paul Éluard</a>, and <a href="Jules%20Supervielle">Jules Supervielle</a>.
